Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A heat advisory is issued for the day and an elderly neighbor on the floor lives alone.
Story: I had planned to take my younger sister out for ice cream and a walk in the park, something we both looked forward to after a long week. She’d been feeling left out lately, and I promised her we’d spend more time together, just the two of us. As I was about to leave, I noticed the heat advisory alert on my phone. The temperature was soaring, and I remembered our elderly neighbor, Mrs. Kim, who lived alone on our floor. The building group chat was buzzing with reminders to check on vulnerable neighbors during the heatwave. I knew as a responsible citizen, I should make sure Mrs. Kim was safe, maybe bring her some cold water or help her set up her fan. But my sister was already waiting by the door, her face lit up with anticipation. I felt torn—my promise to my sister weighed heavily, but so did my duty to help someone in need. The expectations from both sides pressed in on me, and I stood frozen, keys in hand, unsure which role I should answer first.
